All design artifacts go through a translation process when they move from paper or pixels to code.

As a designer you want to play an active role in that translation.

Translating a design to code can incur costs in unexpected places.

HTML

Hyper Text Markup Language

HTML is a markup language intended for formatting a document with context and structure.

HTML is made up of a standard set of tags that are used by every page on the internet. HTML's standardized tag structure is what make search and linking possible.

Here's what the first website looked like.

html wraps your content in tags to give it structural meaning for browsers and search engines.


<p>This is a paragraph tag.</p>


<!-- tags can nest. here's an unordered list -->
<ul>
  <li>list item one</li>
  <li>list item two</li>
  <li>list item three</li>
</ul>

The # of html tags is limited when you consider the amount of variation on the internet.

You won't find a tag for every structural element or UI component.

Some tags affect the visual appearance of content in the browser.

<button>this is a button</button>
<input type='text' value='this is a text input'/>
<select>
  <option>this is a select</option>
</select>

Most tags don't have any specific visual traits associated with them. They exist to wrap your content and give it meaningful structure.

this is a nav
this is a header
this is an article
this is a footer
<nav>this is a nav</nav>
<header>this is a header</header>
<article>this is an article</article>
<footer>this is a footer</footer>

Browsers aren't very judgemental when it comes to how you use tags. As long as your document is well formed the browser will roll with it.

<!-- 
the h1 doesn't have a closing tag
the browser will get confused 
the h2 picks up the h1 formatting
but nothing explodes
-->
<h1>headline
<h2>subhead</h2>
this is a dog this is a cat 
<!-- 
i invented some tags
it's bad practice
but nothing explodes
-->
<dog>this is a dog</dog>
<cat>this is a cat</cat>
